cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
Which female politician and aristocrat said ‘I married beneath me, all women do’?
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: The quote "I married beneath me, all women do" is attributed to a well-known female politician and aristocrat. This statement reflects a perspective on marriage and social status, suggesting that women often marry men of lower social standing. The quote is famously linked to the British politician and socialite, Lady Nancy Astor, who was the first woman to take her seat in the British Parliament. Given her background and the context of the quote, it is likely that she is the person being referred to.

Answer: Lady Nancy Astor

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
Which female politician and aristocrat said ‘I married beneath me, all women do’?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['Queen Sophie Amalie was described as ambitious and was well known to participate in state affairs, with the blessing of her husband, and influence policy as his adviser. Her great influence upon her husband was widely known already before he became king: before Frederick had succeeded to the throne, a satire circulated in which this was caricatured in the form of a mock question: "Can a husband make any decisions whatever without the consent of his wife? Signed Duke Frederick." \n', 'In a 2008 interview for the biography book "La Reina muy cerca" (The Queen Up Close) by Spanish journalist and writer Pilar Urbano, Queen Sofía of Spain sparked controversy by voicing her disapproval of LGBT pride. This was in addition to overstepping her official duties as a member of the Royal Family by censuring the Spanish Law on Marriage in how it names same-sex unions as "matrimonio" (marriage). Without using the slogan "Straight Pride", Queen Sofía was directly quoted as saying that if heterosexuals were to take the streets as the LGBT community does for Gay Pride parades, that the former collective would bring Madrid to a standstill.\n', 'Saint Anne was the patron saint of unmarried women, particularly because of the legend that she had been married three times.\n', 'Friedrich Adolph Riedesel was a member of the line of Riedesel zu Eisenbach, and like all his male cousins had the title of "Freiherr" or Baron. He was not "the Baron" or "von Riedesel." Upon their marriage Frederika gained the title of "Freifrau" or Baroness Riedesel zu Eisenbach. She was described as looking more like an unmarried school girl than a married woman. She would grow into a red-haired baroness, "full in figure and possessing no small share of beauty." In the following years, the Riedesels had two daughters, Gustava and Frederica, and Frederika was pregnant with a third, Carolina, in 1776 when Brunswick signed a treaty to support Great Britain in the suppression of the rebellion in their American colonies. Friedrich was promoted to General and named commander of the Brunswick army, and he referred to Frederika as "Mrs. General".\n', 'During the "Ancien Régime", a female commoner was always addressed as "mademoiselle", even when married, "madame" being limited to women of the high nobility, even if they were not married. This practice ceased after the French Revolution.\n', 'Before he left, Frederick made it known through Sophie to the Empress that he regarded his wife to be as of "poor character" as she behaved with too much informality with servant-lads, grooms and aides, and that the "violence" she accused him of was only his insistence that she should behave with adequate reserve towards them, in keeping with what was regarded as suitable for a woman of her high rank. The allegation of bisexuality was never made known to him, but it is notable that Frederick later had a happy marriage, with no hint of either bisexuality (granted, of course, that as a bisexual man, he would have no problem in having sexual relations with a woman) or violence, with Princess Charlotte of Great Britain.\n', 'When remarking in her diaries on other women who shared their affections with great men of the day, Arbuthnot displayed a sharp, ironic wit. Of Wellington\'s one-time mistress Princess Dorothea Lieven, wife to the Imperial Russian ambassador to London from 1812 to 1834, she wrote "It is curious that the loves and intrigues of a femme galante should have such influence over the affairs of Europe." Arbuthnot obviously failed to realise she was regarded by some in London society as a "femme galante" in a similar situation herself.\n', 'Brigitte Frank had a reputation for having a more dominant personality than her husband: after 1939 she called herself "a queen of Poland" (""Königin von Polen""). The marriage was unhappy and became colder from year to year. When Frank sought a divorce in 1942, Brigitte gave everything to save their marriage in order to remain the "First Lady in the General Government". One of her most famous comments was "I\'d rather be widowed than divorced from a Reichsminister!" Frank answered: "So you are my deadly enemy!"\n', 'Drusilla held the Latin honorary title of "Regina". The Roman historian Suetonius only uses the word "Regina" to describe a queen regnant or a queen consort. According to Suetonius, she is one of the three queens whom Felix married. Her title may have been purely honorary; possibly it reveals Felix\'s influence, the high position to which Claudius had appointed him, and his quasi-royal status in the imperial court. (As explained by the Roman historian Tacitus, Felix and his brother Marcus Antonius Pallas were descended from the Greek kings of Arcadia.) At the time of her first marriage, Drusilla was the only daughter of a king of a former kingdom, which may explain her title; the title may also reveal the identity of her second husband.\n', 'One day it is said: the Countess summoned the groom to her presence, and, to his amazement and embarrassment, told him that she had long grown to love him, and that she asked nothing better of life than to become his wife. Overcome with surprise and confusion, Forbes protested: "But my lady, think of the difference between us. You are one of the greatest ladies in the land, and I am no better than the earth you tread on." "You must not say that", the Countess replied. "You are more to me than rank or riches. These I count as nothing, compared with the happiness you have it in your power to bestow."\n']

Task Description:

   - The passage mentions her ambition and influence in state affairs, suggesting that she was a powerful figure in her time. This context of a strong female presence in politics may relate to the quote, as it reflects the dynamics of marriage and societal expectations for women of high status.

2. **Queen Sofía of Spain**:
   - This passage discusses her controversial views and her role within the royal family. While it does not directly relate to the quote, it highlights the complexities of female aristocrats navigating societal norms, which may provide insight into the mindset of women in power regarding marriage and status.

3. **Frederika Riedesel**:
   - The description of Frederika gaining the title of "Freifrau" and her role as a baroness provides a glimpse into the expectations and societal roles of women in aristocracy. The mention of her being described as beautiful and her husband's military status may reflect the societal pressures and perceptions surrounding marriage among the elite.

4. **Brigitte Frank**:
   - The passage about Brigitte Frank's marriage and her desire to remain the "First Lady" despite an unhappy marriage illustrates the sacrifices and societal expectations faced by women in powerful positions. Her quote about preferring widowhood to divorce underscores the stigma attached to divorce and the importance of status in marriage.

5. **Countess and Groom**:
   - This passage illustrates the theme of love transcending social class, as the Countess expresses her feelings for a man of lower status. This narrative aligns with the quote by highlighting the societal barriers and expectations regarding marriage, particularly for women of high rank.

The extracted content provides a backdrop of the societal norms and expectations surrounding marriage for women in aristocracy and politics. The quote in question reflects a common sentiment among women of high status, suggesting that they often felt compelled to marry men of lower status due to societal pressures or the limitations placed on their choices.

The passages collectively illustrate the struggles and complexities faced by women in power, which can help identify the speaker as someone who navigated these challenges, possibly hinting at figures like **Lady Mary Wortley Montagu**, who is often attributed with similar sentiments regarding marriage and social status.

In conclusion, the content extracted from the passages enriches the understanding of the quote by providing context about the societal dynamics of marriage among women of high rank, which is crucial for identifying the speaker and understanding the implications of her statement.

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

The quote "I married beneath me, all women do" is often attributed to Lady Nancy Astor, a prominent British politician and socialite who was the first woman to take her seat in the British Parliament in 1919. This statement reflects a critical perspective on the institution of marriage, particularly for women of high social standing, suggesting that they often find themselves in relationships with men of lower status due to societal norms and expectations.

To better understand the context of this quote, we can draw upon the extracted content from the passages provided:

1. **Queen Sophie Amalie**: Her influence in state affairs and her role as an adviser to her husband highlight the complexities of female power within marriage. This context reinforces the idea that women of high status often navigate societal expectations that may limit their choices in marriage.

2. **Queen Sofía of Spain**: The discussion of her controversial views and her navigation of royal duties illustrates the challenges faced by women in aristocracy. This reflects the broader societal pressures that women like Astor would have encountered, particularly regarding their roles in marriage and public life.

3. **Frederika Riedesel**: The passage about Frederika gaining the title of "Freifrau" and her societal expectations as a baroness provides insight into the pressures women face regarding marriage and status. It underscores the notion that women often marry for social standing rather than personal choice.

4. **Brigitte Frank**: Her desire to maintain her status as "First Lady" despite an unhappy marriage emphasizes the importance of social position in marital relationships. This aligns with the sentiment expressed in the quote, highlighting the sacrifices women make to uphold their societal roles.

5. **Countess and Groom**: This narrative illustrates the theme of love versus social class, emphasizing the barriers women face when choosing partners. It aligns with the quote by showing that women of high rank often feel constrained by societal expectations in their marital choices.

By synthesizing this information, we can infer that Lady Nancy Astor's quote encapsulates a broader sentiment shared by many women in positions of power. It reflects the tension between personal desires and societal expectations, particularly regarding marriage. The historical context of female politicians and aristocrats reveals that many women felt compelled to marry beneath their status due to societal norms, which often dictated their choices.

### Answer:
Lady Nancy Astor

Engage in a dialogue where you imagine discussing these passages with a group of experts. Each expert presents different perspectives based on the foundational and advanced knowledge from the passages. By participating in this collaborative discussion, you will deepen the model's understanding through the synthesis of multiple expert perspectives.

**Expert Discussion on the Quote: "I married beneath me, all women do."**

**Expert 1: Historian of Aristocracy**
The quote attributed to a female politician and aristocrat reflects a long-standing societal norm where women of high status often married men of lower social standing. This practice was not uncommon in history, as seen in the passage about the Countess who expressed her love for a man of lesser rank. This sentiment illustrates the tension between personal desire and societal expectations, which has been a recurring theme in aristocratic marriages.

**Expert 2: Gender Studies Scholar**
From a gender studies perspective, the quote underscores the systemic inequalities faced by women, particularly in aristocratic contexts. The idea that women "marry beneath" them speaks to the patriarchal structures that devalue women's choices and agency. The passage about Queen Sophie Amalie shows how women could wield influence, yet they were still often constrained by their marital choices. This reflects a broader societal issue where women's worth is often tied to their marital status and the status of their husbands.

**Expert 3: Literary Analyst**
The quote can also be interpreted through a literary lens, where it serves as a critique of societal norms. The irony in the statement suggests a deeper commentary on the roles women are forced to play in society. The passage about Arbuthnot's observations on women and their relationships with powerful men highlights this irony, as it reveals the complexities of female influence and the often unrecognized power dynamics at play.

**Expert 4: Sociologist**
From a sociological standpoint, the quote can be seen as a reflection of the social structures that dictate marriage patterns. The historical context of marriages among the aristocracy often involved strategic alliances rather than romantic love. The passage regarding Brigitte Frank illustrates the lengths to which women would go to maintain their status, indicating that marriage was often a transaction rather than a union based on affection.

**Points of Agreement:**
All experts agree that the quote reflects the historical and societal constraints placed on women, particularly in aristocratic contexts. They recognize that marriage often served as a means of social mobility or stability, rather than a personal choice based on love. The discussions highlight the interplay between personal agency and societal expectations.

**Points of Disagreement:**
While the historian emphasizes the historical prevalence of marrying beneath one's status, the gender studies scholar focuses on the implications of such marriages on women's agency. The literary analyst points out the irony and critique embedded in the quote, while the sociologist emphasizes the transactional nature of these marriages. This divergence in focus illustrates the multifaceted nature of the topic.

**Cohesive Summary:**
The quote "I married beneath me, all women do" serves as a poignant reflection on the historical and societal dynamics of marriage among women of aristocratic status. Through the lens of various experts, it becomes clear that this statement encapsulates the tension between personal desire and societal expectations, revealing the systemic inequalities that have historically constrained women's choices. The discussions highlight the complexities of female agency, the transactional nature of aristocratic marriages, and the enduring critique of societal norms that dictate women's roles. By synthesizing these perspectives, we gain a deeper understanding of the quote's implications, illustrating how historical practices continue to resonate in contemporary discussions about gender and power.

In the following years, the Riedesels had two daughters, Gustava and Frederica, and Frederika was pregnant with a third, Carolina, in 1776 when Brunswick signed a treaty to support Great Britain in the suppression of the rebellion in their American colonies. Friedrich was promoted to General and named commander of the Brunswick army, and he referred to Frederika as "Mrs. General".
', 'During the "Ancien Régime", a female commoner was always addressed as "mademoiselle", even when married, "madame" being limited to women of the high nobility, even if they were not married. This practice ceased after the French Revolution.
', 'Before he left, Frederick made it known through Sophie to the Empress that he regarded his wife to be as of "poor character" as she behaved with too much informality with servant-lads, grooms and aides, and that the "violence" she accused him of was only his insistence that she should behave with adequate reserve towards them, in keeping with what was regarded as suitable for a woman of her high rank. The allegation of bisexuality was never made known to him, but it is notable that Frederick later had a happy marriage, with no hint of either bisexuality (granted, of course, that as a bisexual man, he would have no problem in having sexual relations with a woman) or violence, with Princess Charlotte of Great Britain.
', 'When remarking in her diaries on other women who shared their affections with great men of the day, Arbuthnot displayed a sharp, ironic wit. Of Wellington's one-time mistress Princess Dorothea Lieven, wife to the Imperial Russian ambassador to London from 1812 to 1834, she wrote "It is curious that the loves and intrigues of a femme galante should have such influence over the affairs of Europe." Arbuthnot obviously failed to realise she was regarded by some in London society as a "femme galante" in a similar situation herself.
', 'Brigitte Frank had a reputation for having a more dominant personality than her husband: after 1939 she called herself "a queen of Poland" (""Königin von Polen""). The marriage was unhappy and became colder from year to year. When Frank sought a divorce in 1942, Brigitte gave everything to save their marriage in order to remain the "First Lady in the General Government". One of her most famous comments was "I'd rather be widowed than divorced from a Reichsminister!" Frank answered: "So you are my deadly enemy!"
', 'Drusilla held the Latin honorary title of "Regina". The Roman historian Suetonius only uses the word "Regina" to describe a queen regnant or a queen consort. According to Suetonius, she is one of the three queens whom Felix married. Her title may have been purely honorary; possibly it reveals Felix's influence, the high position to which Claudius had appointed him, and his quasi-royal status in the imperial court. (As explained by the Roman historian Tacitus, Felix and his brother Marcus Antonius Pallas were descended from the Greek kings of Arcadia.) At the time of her first marriage, Drusilla was the only daughter of a king of a former kingdom, which may explain her title; the title may also reveal the identity of her second husband.
', 'One day it is said: the Countess summoned the groom to her presence, and, to his amazement and embarrassment, told him that she had long grown to love him, and that she asked nothing better of life than to become his wife. Overcome with surprise and confusion, Forbes protested: "But my lady, think of the difference between us. You are one of the greatest ladies in the land, and I am no better than the earth you tread on." "You must not say that", the Countess replied. "You are more to me than rank or riches. These I count as nothing, compared with the happiness you have it in your power to bestow."
']

question_info.question: Which female politician and aristocrat said ‘I married beneath me, all women do’?
passages:
Queen Sophie Amalie was described as ambitious and was well known to participate in state affairs, with the blessing of her husband, and influence policy as his adviser. Her great influence upon her husband was widely known already before he became king: before Frederick had succeeded to the throne, a satire circulated in which this was caricatured in the form of a mock question: "Can a husband make any decisions whatever without the consent of his wife? Signed Duke Frederick." 
In a 2008 interview for the biography book "La Reina muy cerca" (The Queen Up Close) by Spanish journalist and writer Pilar Urbano, Queen Sofía of Spain sparked controversy by voicing her disapproval of LGBT pride. This was in addition to overstepping her official duties as a member of the Royal Family by censuring the Spanish Law on Marriage in how it names same-sex unions as "matrimonio" (marriage). Without using the slogan "Straight Pride", Queen Sofía was directly quoted as saying that if heterosexuals were to take the streets as the LGBT community does for Gay Pride parades, that the former collective would bring Madrid to a standstill.
Saint Anne was the patron saint of unmarried women, particularly because of the legend that she had been married three times.
Friedrich Adolph Riedesel was a member of the line of Riedesel zu Eisenbach, and like all his male cousins had the title of "Freiherr" or Baron. He was not "the Baron" or "von Riedesel." Upon their marriage Frederika gained the title of "Freifrau" or Baroness Riedesel zu Eisenbach. She was described as looking more like an unmarried school girl than a married woman. She would grow into a red-haired baroness, "full in figure and possessing no small share of beauty." In the following years, the Riedesels had two daughters, Gustava and Frederica, and Frederika was pregnant with a third, Carolina, in 1776 when Brunswick signed a treaty to support Great Britain in the suppression of the rebellion in their American colonies. Friedrich was promoted to General and named commander of the Brunswick army, and he referred to Frederika as "Mrs. General".
During the "Ancien Régime", a female commoner was always addressed as "mademoiselle", even when married, "madame" being limited to women of the high nobility, even if they were not married. This practice ceased after the French Revolution.
Before he left, Frederick made it known through Sophie to the Empress that he regarded his wife to be as of "poor character" as she behaved with too much informality with servant-lads, grooms and aides, and that the "violence" she accused him of was only his insistence that she should behave with adequate reserve towards them, in keeping with what was regarded as suitable for a woman of her high rank. The allegation of bisexuality was never made known to him, but it is notable that Frederick later had a happy marriage, with no hint of either bisexuality (granted, of course, that as a bisexual man, he would have no problem in having sexual relations with a woman) or violence, with Princess Charlotte of Great Britain.
When remarking in her diaries on other women who shared their affections with great men of the day, Arbuthnot displayed a sharp, ironic wit. Of Wellington's one-time mistress Princess Dorothea Lieven, wife to the Imperial Russian ambassador to London from 1812 to 1834, she wrote "It is curious that the loves and intrigues of a femme galante should have such influence over the affairs of Europe." Arbuthnot obviously failed to realise she was regarded by some in London society as a "femme galante" in a similar situation herself.
Brigitte Frank had a reputation for having a more dominant personality than her husband: after 1939 she called herself "a queen of Poland" (""Königin von Polen""). The marriage was unhappy and became colder from year to year. When Frank sought a divorce in 1942, Brigitte gave everything to save their marriage in order to remain the "First Lady in the General Government". One of her most famous comments was "I'd rather be widowed than divorced from a Reichsminister!" Frank answered: "So you are my deadly enemy!"
Drusilla held the Latin honorary title of "Regina". The Roman historian Suetonius only uses the word "Regina" to describe a queen regnant or a queen consort. According to Suetonius, she is one of the three queens whom Felix married. Her title may have been purely honorary; possibly it reveals Felix's influence, the high position to which Claudius had appointed him, and his quasi-royal status in the imperial court. (As explained by the Roman historian Tacitus, Felix and his brother Marcus Antonius Pallas were descended from the Greek kings of Arcadia.) At the time of her first marriage, Drusilla was the only daughter of a king of a former kingdom, which may explain her title; the title may also reveal the identity of her second husband.
One day it is said: the Countess summoned the groom to her presence, and, to his amazement and embarrassment, told him that she had long grown to love him, and that she asked nothing better of life than to become his wife. Overcome with surprise and confusion, Forbes protested: "But my lady, think of the difference between us. You are one of the greatest ladies in the land, and I am no better than the earth you tread on." "You must not say that", the Countess replied. "You are more to me than rank or riches. These I count as nothing, compared with the happiness you have it in your power to bestow."
__answers__: Nancy Witcher Astor, Viscountess Astor, CH
